metadata.titleEn: The data of oxygen isotope, dust, anion and accumulation of the Dasuopu Ice Core on the Tibetan Plateau (1997)
metadata.description:
This data set comprises the oxygen isotope, dust, anion and accumulation data of the two ice cores drilled from the Dasuopu glacier on the Tibetan Plateau in 1997. The depth of the Dasuopu ice core 2(C2) is 149.2 meters, while that of the Dasuopu ice core 3(C3) is 167.7 meters. C3 was drilled from the top of the glacier, and C2 was drilled 100 meters below.
The data set contains 3 tables: the oxygen isotope, dust, and main anion average data of Dasuopu ice core 3 (1450-1996), the 10-year of oxygen isotope, dust, and main anion average data of Dasuopu ice core 3 (1000-1996), and the accumulation data of Dasuopu ice cores 2 and 3（1442-1996）. 
Source of the data：National Centers for Environmental Information（http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/data-access/paleoclimatology-data/datasets/ice-core） 
Table 1：The annual average data of oxygen isotope, dust, and main anion of Dasuopu ice core 3 (1450-1996) 
a. Name interpretation 
Field 1：time
Field 2：oxygen isotope 
Field 3：dust (diameter 0.63-20 um) 
Field 4：Cl- 
Field 5：NO3- 
Field 6：SO42- 
b. Dimension（unit of measurement） 
Field 1：dimensionless 
Field 2：‰
Field 3：particles/mL
Field 4：ppb
Field 5：ppb 
Field 6：ppb 
Table 2：The 10-year oxygen isotope, dust, and main anion data of Dasuopu ice core 3 (1000-1996) 
a. Name interpretation 
Field 1：start time
Field 2：end time 
Field 3：oxygen isotope 
Field 4：dust (diameter 0.63-20 um) 
Field 5：Cl- 
Field 6：NO3-
Field 7：SO42- 
b. Dimension（unit of measurement） 
Field 1：dimensionless 
Field 2：dimensionless
Field 3：‰ 
Field 4：particles/mL 
Field 5：ppb 
Field 6：ppb 
Field 7：ppb
Table 3：the accumulation data of Dasuopu ice cores 2 and 3 （1442-1996） 
a. Name interpretation 
Field 1：time
Field 2：ice core 2 
Field 3：ice core 3 
B. Dimension （unit of measurement） 
Field 1：dimensionless 
Field 2：cm/yr 
Field 3：cm/yr

authorList.unitEn: Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research, CAS

literatureList.titleEn: A high-resolution millennial record of the South Asian Monsoon from Himalayan ice cores
literatureList.referenceEn: Thompson, L.G., Yao, T.D., Mosley-Thompson, E., Davis, M.E., Henderson, K.A., &Lin,P.N. (2000). A high-resolution millennial record of the South Asian Monsoon from Himalayan ice cores. Science, 289(5486), 1916-1919.

projectList.titleEn: National Tibetan Plateau / Third Pole Environment Data Center

background: The Holocene climate of the southern Tibetan Plateau has been dominated by the South Asian Monsoon in the summer and by westerly cyclonic activity in the winter. The strength of the monsoon is determined by a number of forcing mechanisms operating over a variety of time scales. Northern Hemisphere (NH) insolation has been relatively high over the past 10,000 years with correspondingly greater monsoonal activity than during the last glacial stage, when NH insolation was lower. At that time, reduced differential heating between the Indian Ocean and the Asian continent weakened the summer circulation, producing cooler, drier conditions over Asia and across the southern plateau. On shorter time scales, variations in the strength of the South Asian Monsoon have been explained by changes in internal boundary conditions, such as increasing tropical sea surface temperatures, variations in Eurasian snow cover, and linkages with the El Niño–Southern Oscillation (ENSO). The Himalayas contain the largest volume of ice outside the polar regions, and the meltwater from its glaciers form the headwaters of such important rivers as the Indus and the Ganges.
research objective: Here, we examine the variability of the South Asian Monsoon as recovered from Himalayan ice cores.
methods: In 1997, three ice cores were recovered from the Dasuopu glacier (28°23'N, 85°43'E) with the use of an electromechanical drill in dry holes. The first core (C1) was 159.9 m long and was drilled at 7000 m above sea level (a.s.l.) down the flow line from the top of the col, and two cores (C2 and C3), 149.2 and 167.7 m long, respectively, were drilled to bedrock 100 m apart on the col at 7200 m a.s.l. All cores were analyzed over their entire lengths for oxygen isotopic ratio (d18O), chemical composition, and dust concentration. Most of the results presented here are from C3, which was cut into 6903 samples for both d18O and hydrogen isotopes (dD) and into 6419 samples each for insoluble dust, chloride (Cl–), sulfate (SO4 2–), and nitrate (NO3 2) analyses. Borehole temperatures were –16.0°C at 10 m depth and –13.8°C at the ice-bedrock contact, demonstrating that the Dasuopu glacier is frozen to its bed.
findings: The Dasuopu d18O record, like that of Dunde, suggests evidence of a significant 20th-century warming. This isotopic warming is the most regionally consistent climate signal of the last 1000 years.

Verification.Question: Is the electromechanical drill a valid method for extracting ice cores in the Tibetan Plateau region?
Are ice cores from the Dasuopu glacier analyzed for both insoluble dust and major anions like chloride and sulfate?

Disjunctive.Question: Are datasets on Himalayan ice cores more focused on isotopic ratios, chemical composition, or dust concentration?
Disjunctive.Answer: isotopic ratios, chemical composition, dust concentration

Concept Completion.Question: What are the key data collection methods used for obtaining ice core samples from glaciers?
Where were the ice cores drilled from the Dasuopu glacier, and what were their respective depths?
Concept Completion.Answer: Dasuopu glacier 7200 m a.s.l Core C2 149.2 m Core C3 167.7 m

Concept Completion.Question: When were the ice cores from the Dasuopu glacier collected, and what was the primary focus of analysis?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to retrieve ice core samples in the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: In 1997, three ice cores were retrieved from the Dasuopu glacier using an electromechanical drill in dry holes. The cores were drilled at elevations around 7000 to 7200 meters above sea level.

Example.Question: What is an example of an analytical approach to measure chemical compositions in ice core samples from the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: The ice cores from the Dasuopu glacier were analyzed over their entire lengths for oxygen isotopic ratio, chemical composition, and dust concentration. Specific analyses included measuring oxygen isotopes (d18O), hydrogen isotopes (dD), insoluble dust, chloride (Cl–), sulfate (SO4 2–), and nitrate (NO3 2).

Feature Specification.Question: What are the essential features of an ice core dataset collected from high-altitude glaciers?
Feature Specification.Answer: oxygen isotopic ratios, chemical compositions, dust concentrations, hydrogen isotopes, insoluble dust, chloride, sulfate, nitrate

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key characteristics of data collection methods used in extracting ice cores from glaciers?
Feature Specification.Answer: electromechanical drill, dry holes, 149.2 meters, 167.7 meters, drilled to bedrock, 7200 meters, isotopic compositions, chemical compositions

Feature Specification.Question: What are the primary attributes of datasets that analyze the variability of the South Asian Monsoon using ice core data?
Feature Specification.Answer: oxygen isotopic ratios, chemical compositions, extensive time periods, annual or decadal averages, dust concentration, major anions like chloride, sulfate, nitrate

Quantification.Question: How many samples were analyzed for oxygen isotopic ratios, chemical composition, and dust concentration in the ice cores collected from the Dasuopu glacier?
What is the total length of the ice cores extracted from the Dasuopu glacier for data collection on oxygen isotopes, dust, and anions?
How many different data tables are included in the collection that contains information on oxygen isotopes, dust, major anions, and accumulation amounts from the Dasuopu ice cores?

Definition.Question: What is the meaning of 'oxygen isotopic ratio' in the context of ice core analysis?
Definition.Answer: The 'oxygen isotopic ratio' in the context of ice core analysis refers to the measurement of the ratios of oxygen isotopes, such as δ18O, in ice cores. This ratio provides insights into past temperatures and climatic conditions, as it reflects changes in the isotopic composition of precipitation over time.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'borehole temperatures' in glacier studies?
Definition.Answer: 'Borehole temperatures' in glacier studies are measurements taken at various depths within a glacier to determine the thermal state of the ice. These temperatures help assess whether the glacier is frozen to its bed or if there is melting at the base, which can influence glacier dynamics and stability.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the data collection challenges of measuring oxygen isotopes and dust concentrations in the Dasuopu glacier compare with similar measurements in other climatic regions?
Comparison.Answer: The Dasuopu glacier data collection involves challenges such as maintaining borehole temperatures and ensuring accurate sampling at high altitudes. These challenges are specific to the high-altitude, cold environment of the Tibetan Plateau and may differ from other regions where temperature and altitude might not pose such significant barriers to collecting precise oxygen isotope and dust concentration data.

Interpretation.Question: How might the spatial location and depth of ice core drilling affect the interpretation of climate variability in datasets derived from glacial ice cores?
Interpretation.Answer: The spatial location and depth of ice core drilling are crucial for interpreting climate variability, as they can influence the type of climatic information captured. Ice cores drilled at different depths and locations, such as those from different elevations on a glacier, may record varying climatic conditions, reflecting local environmental changes and broader climatic trends over time.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might variations in the strength of the South Asian Monsoon be significant for interpreting ice core data from the Himalayas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Variations in the strength of the South Asian Monsoon are significant because they affect the climate conditions that are archived in the ice cores. For example, changes in tropical sea surface temperatures, Eurasian snow cover, and ENSO linkages can influence monsoon strength, which in turn affects the precipitation and temperature patterns recorded in the isotopic and chemical compositions of the ice cores.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the potential consequences of using electromechanical drills in dry holes for ice core extraction on the integrity and quality of the extracted data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using electromechanical drills in dry holes can help in preserving the integrity and quality of the extracted ice cores by reducing the risk of contamination and mechanical disturbances. This method allows for precise extraction of ice cores as seen in the Dasuopu glacier, where it enabled detailed analysis of oxygen isotopic ratios, chemical composition, and dust concentration.

Causal Consequence.Question: What outcomes could arise from analyzing the isotopic and chemical composition data from ice cores for comprehending regional climate signals over the last millennium?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Analyzing isotopic and chemical composition data from ice cores can lead to the identification of significant climate signals, such as regional warming trends. In the case of the Dasuopu glacier, the isotopic data suggested a notable 20th-century warming, which is considered the most regionally consistent climate signal of the last 1000 years. Such outcomes are critical for understanding long-term climate variability and its impact on the region.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of collecting oxygen isotope and dust concentration data from ice cores in the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective of collecting oxygen isotope and dust concentration data from ice cores in the Tibetan Plateau is to examine the variability of the South Asian Monsoon as it has been recorded in Himalayan ice cores, providing insights into historical climate patterns and monsoon strength.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to analyze chemical compositions such as chloride, sulfate, and nitrate in ice cores from the Dasuopu glacier?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Analyzing chemical compositions such as chloride, sulfate, and nitrate in ice cores from the Dasuopu glacier is important to understand the historical climate conditions, including atmospheric circulation patterns and environmental changes over time, which can impact regional climate dynamics.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended outcomes of drilling multiple ice cores at different depths and locations on the Dasuopu glacier?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended outcomes of drilling multiple ice cores at different depths and locations on the Dasuopu glacier are to obtain comprehensive data on past climate conditions, including temperature and precipitation patterns, by analyzing the isotopic and chemical compositions throughout different layers of the glacier, which can inform studies on climate change and regional climate variability.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What specific procedures are used to drill and retrieve ice cores from glaciers located at high altitudes like the Dasuopu glacier?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In 1997, ice cores were retrieved from the Dasuopu glacier using an electromechanical drill in dry holes. The cores were drilled to bedrock, with one core drilled down the flow line from the top of the col and two others drilled 100 m apart on the col at a high altitude of around 7200 m above sea level.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are the collected ice cores processed to analyze oxygen isotopes, chemical composition, and dust concentration?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The ice cores were analyzed over their entire lengths for oxygen isotopic ratio (d18O), chemical composition, and dust concentration. Specifically, core C3 was cut into samples for both d18O and hydrogen isotopes (dD), and into additional samples for analyzing insoluble dust, chloride (Cl–), sulfate (SO4 2–), and nitrate (NO3 2).

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enabled the extraction and analysis of ice cores from high-altitude glaciers such as the Dasuopu glacier?
Enablement.Answer: In 1997, ice cores were extracted from the Dasuopu glacier using an electromechanical drill in dry holes, which allowed for the recovery of cores from high-altitude areas like 7200 m above sea level.

Enablement.Question: How do specific data collection methods enable the analysis of oxygen isotopes and other chemical components in ice cores?
Enablement.Answer: The cores were analyzed over their entire lengths for oxygen isotopic ratio (d18O), chemical composition, and dust concentration, with core C3 being cut into thousands of samples for these analyses, enabling detailed examination of isotopic and chemical data.

Enablement.Question: What conditions are necessary for the accurate collection and preservation of ice core data from remote high-altitude locations?
Enablement.Answer: Borehole temperatures were measured at –16.0°C at 10 m depth and –13.8°C at the ice-bedrock contact, demonstrating that the Dasuopu glacier is frozen to its bed, which is crucial for the preservation of ice core data.

Expectation.Question: Why might the isotopic warming signals from ice cores on the Tibetan Plateau be a robust indicator of regional climate change over the past millennium?
Expectation.Answer: The isotopic warming signals from ice cores, such as those from the Dasuopu glacier, are considered robust indicators of regional climate change because they have shown consistency with other records, like the Dunde ice core, and provide a significant climate signal that reflects the broader patterns of 20th-century warming across the region.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could the analysis of dust concentration in ice cores enhance our understanding of historical atmospheric conditions, and what methodological considerations should be taken into account?
Judgmental.Answer: Analyzing dust concentration in ice cores can enhance our understanding of historical atmospheric conditions by revealing changes in wind patterns, source regions of dust, and the frequency of dust storm events. Methodological considerations include ensuring precise measurement of particle size and concentration, accounting for potential contamination, and correlating findings with other climatic variables such as isotopic data and chemical markers.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about how data from different depths of ice cores can reflect historical climate variations.
Assertion.Answer: Data from different depths of ice cores reflect historical climate variations by providing chronological records of isotopic composition, dust concentration, and chemical composition. The depth of the ice core corresponds to different time periods, allowing researchers to infer climatic conditions over time, as shown by the 6903 samples analyzed for d18O and hydrogen isotopes from core C3.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand why measuring both chemical composition and dust concentration in ice cores is important for climate studies.
Assertion.Answer: Measuring both chemical composition and dust concentration in ice cores is important because they provide insights into past atmospheric conditions and climate changes. Chemical compositions like Cl–, SO4 2–, and NO3 2–, along with dust concentration, can indicate variations in monsoon strength, atmospheric circulation patterns, and other climatic factors over time, as evidenced by the analyses of the Dasuopu glacier ice cores.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential sources for expanding datasets related to oxygen isotopes and dust concentrations in glacier ice cores.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential sources for expanding datasets on oxygen isotopes and dust concentrations in glacier ice cores include additional ice cores from different glaciers on the Tibetan Plateau and other high-altitude regions, as well as collaborations with institutions like the National Centers for Environmental Information, which provide access to paleoclimatology data and datasets.
